title: Sid Goodwin
text:
Sid Goodwin (1914–1980) was an Australian <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1930s and 1940s. He played on the for the <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain</a> and <a href="Newtown%20Jets">Newtown</a> clubs in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20premiership">New South Wales Rugby Football League premiership</a> and also represented <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a> and Australia. Goodwin played 11 seasons for the <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain</a> club between 1933–1942 then moved to the <a href="Newtown%20Jets">Newtown</a> club for 3 seasons between 1943–1945. He was selected to play for <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales</a> in 1938, 1939, 1940 and 1944.
Balmain.
In 1935, Goodwin took Balmain's club record for most tries in a match with 5 against <a href="Sydney%20University%20rugby%20league%20team">University</a> on 4 April. Also in 1935, he was also selected to represent <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia</a> in all three Tests against New Zealand. He is listed on the "Australian Players Register" as kangaroo No. 199. In 1936 he played in his first Grand Final, scoring a try in Balmain's loss to Easts.
In 1939 Goodwin was the premiership's top try-scorer and also captained the Balmain side that won the <a href="1939%20NSWRFL%20season">1939 Grand Final</a>. By the time he left Balmain he'd set the club's records for most tries in a season and most career tries. Goodwin was inducted into the Balmain Tigers Hall of Fame on 20 March 2007.
Newtown.
After moving to <a href="Newtown%20Jets">Newtown</a> in 1943, Goodwin enjoyed further premiership success in <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201943">NSWRFL season 1943</a>, scoring a double in that year's Grand Final. He was again the League's top try-scorer in 1943 and 1944. In 1944 he again played for <a href="Newtown%20Jets">Newtown</a> in the Grand Final, but failed to win against his old club, Balmain.
Post-playing.
Goodwin lived for most of his life in <a href="Marrickville%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Marrickville, New South Wales</a>, but moved to <a href="Windang%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Windang, New South Wales</a> in his retirement. He died there on 24 March 1980, age 65. He was cremated at Wollongong Crematorium on 26 March 1980.
